title: Angular momentum cons - cylinders on sliding rod

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> shows two identical cylinders, each of mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>, that are attached to the ends of a rod of negligible mass. The centers of the cylinders are a distance <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>ℓ</mo></math> apart, and the cylinders-rod system rotates with negligible friction about an axle. The radii of the cylinders is small compared to <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>ℓ</mo></math>. The center of the rod is initially in line with the axle, with the system rotating at an angular velocity <math alttext="omega sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> in the counterclockwise direction as shown. A mechanism attached to the axle rotates along with the system and can slide the rod sideways without exerting a net torque on the rod. As the system rotates, the mechanism slides the rod until the rod’s center is located a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> from the axle, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, at which time the system has an angular velocity <math alttext="omega sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Note: The sliding mechanism can be considered to have negligible rotational inertia, owing to its location at the axle and its small size. (a) Indicate whether <math alttext="omega sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="omega sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. Justify your claim without deriving or manipulating equations.
